text: [music playing]
LEE ABBAMONTE: Hi, there.
I'm Lee Abbamonte.

I was the youngest
American to visit

every country in the world
plus the north and south poles.

I fly a quarter
million miles a year,

so I definitely
like to keep moving.

Here are some travel tips to
make you a better traveler.
[music playing]

When you're going
to the airport,

you have to weigh the
time and the cost.

I live in New York, but
no matter where you live,

you have to weigh the benefit
of taking public transportation,

like a train, or a car
service, like an Uber, Lyft,
Via, taxi, or even a limousine.
Now, there's, benefits to both.

A train can take forever,
or it can be quick,

but you also have to get to
and from the train station,

and you have to deal with
a lot of other people.

Ride shares can be great,
because it's private.

But at the same time,
it can take forever

because of traffic,
and during peak times,

the surge pricing can be
brutal on your wallet.

So you really have to weigh
the cost versus the time
of going to the airport.
[music playing]

Obtaining airline status is easy
if you fly a few times a year.

You get to board
the plane first,

you don't have to wait
in line at check-in,
and you get free checked bags.

There's a lot of
advantages there,

so it's worth being
loyal, even if it's

just for a couple of flights
to obtain that status.

Then when you get
status, you can

take advantage of these
perks, and you can be
a frequent flyer, just like me.

- Here's your boarding pass.
LEE ABBAMONTE: Thank you.
- Have a good one.
LEE ABBAMONTE: All right.

Your toiletry bag is one of
the most important things

that you'll have
in your carry-on.

Pack it at the top of your bag
so you have easy access to it,

and pack the things that
you might need at the top
of your toiletry bag.

For instance, if you're going
to land in someplace tropical,

like Bali, have
something like sunscreen

readily available for
when you walk outside.

If you're landing someplace
dry, like Las Vegas or Phoenix,

you might want to have
Chapstick readily available.

And of course, and this is
important for everybody,

always, always have deodorant
handy, because nobody
wants to be that stinky guy.
[music playing]
Ugh!
Delayed.

There's nothing more
annoying than being delayed
or canceled at the airport.

But here's a tip that a
lot of people don't know.

Take out your phone,
and tweet the airline.

If they don't follow you on
Twitter, ask them to follow you
and they will.

Give them your confirmation
number, your flight number,

and either know the flight that
you want to be switched to,
or ask them for recommendations.

This way, you don't have
to call and be put on hold.

You don't have to stand in
line forever at the airport.
This is the best way to go.

It's worked for me
dozens of times.
[music playing]

Always make sure your devices
are charged beforehand,

because you don't want to rely
on the plane having outlets,
and they don't always work.

So be smart, charge
beforehand, and always
have the power pack in reserve.
[music playing]

For more expert travel
tips and stories,

check out my website
LeeAbbamonte.com,

or follow me on Instagram
or Twitter, @LeeAbbamonte.
Thanks guys.
